item.title: A new default web stack
item.description:
Summary

When building a new web application, the default set of tools used to be a web framework such as Django and a relational database such as PostgreSQL. In 2014, these tools are no longer enough. In this talk, I'll present a new default stack to help build applications that are faster, more robust, easy to scale and still support rapid iteration and fast feature development.
item.dc:creator: Simon Willison

item.dc:creator: James Bennett

item.title: Challenges in developing a large Django site
item.description:
Summary

[EuroPython 2011] Simon Willison - 22 June 2011 in "Track Spaghetti"

Description

Django makes it easy to build web sites and applications on tight deadlines - but how does it deal with sites that scale up in both traffic and complexity? Using Lanyrd.com as a case study, this talk will explore tricks and techniques for taking advantage of what Django has to offer while coping with the unexpected challenges raised by a highly dynamic social web application.

Topics covered will include performance monitoring and optimisation, advanced caching tricks, denormalisation with Solr and Redis and finding the right balance between technical elegance and pragmatism.
item.dc:creator: Simon Willison

item.title: Advanced Aspects of the Django Ecosystem: Haystack, Celery & Fabric
item.description:
Summary

[EuroPython 2011] Simon Willison - 21 June 2011 in "Track Spaghetti"

Description

Django benefits from a thriving third-party ecosystem. This talk will take a deep look at three of the components I have found most useful in my own projects: Haystack for full-text search, Celery for offline processing and Fabric for automated eployments. I'll discuss how we use them for Lanyrd.com, and demonstrate why they deserve a permanent place in your toolbox.
item.dc:creator: Simon Willison
